hedline.hl1: L.I. Man Found Dead In Explosion and Fire

abstract.p: Ronald Tortorella, 62-year-old gunsmith, is found dead in his house in Amityville, New York, after explosion and fire (S)

block.p: A 62-year-old gunsmith was found dead in his house on Long Island after an explosion and fire there last night, the Suffolk County police said.

The victim, Ronald Tortorella, had ammunition in his Amityville house, but it was not clear whether it contributed to the explosion, said Officer Randy Jaret, a police spokesman. ''We haven't determined the cause at this point,'' he said. ''It's something we'll be looking into tomorrow.''
A 62-year-old gunsmith was found dead in his house on Long Island after an explosion and fire there last night, the Suffolk County police said.

The victim, Ronald Tortorella, had ammunition in his Amityville house, but it was not clear whether it contributed to the explosion, said Officer Randy Jaret, a police spokesman. ''We haven't determined the cause at this point,'' he said. ''It's something we'll be looking into tomorrow.''

Mr. Tortorella, who lived in the one-story ranch-style home at 31 Grand Central Avenue with his wife, a daughter and a granddaughter, was home alone at the time of the explosion, around 7:40 p.m., Officer Jaret said. Firefighters extinguished the fire, which destroyed most of the house, and found Mr. Tortorella's body in the kitchen, Officer Jaret said.
The cause of death had not been determined last night.

Kenneth Kaczmarski, who lives a few doors away from the Tortorellas' house and went out to watch the fire, said that as the house burned he could hear popping noises. ''Then a cop came down the street and said there were explosives in there and told us all to move back,'' he said.
